{{short description|French navy diver. First scuba fatality using aqualung for a depth record attempt }} {{Infobox person |name =Maurice Fargues |image =Fargues.jpg |alt = |caption =Maurice Fargues before his fatal deep dive attempt. |birth_name = |birth_date ={{Birth date|1913|4|23}} |birth_place =[[Avignon]], [[France]] |death_date ={{Death-date and age|September 17, 1947|1913}} |death_place =[[Toulon]], [[France]] |nationality =[[French people|French]] |other_names = |known_for =[[Underwater diving|Diver]] |occupation = }} '''Maurice Fargues''' (April 23, 1913 – September 17, 1947) was a [[Underwater diving|diver]] with the [[French Navy]] and a close associate of commander [[Philippe Tailliez]] and deputy commander [[Jacques Cousteau]].<ref name="Plaque">{{cite web|url=http://www.scuba-museum.com/images/album6/index.html|title=INAUGURATION DE LA SALLE MAURICE FARGUES|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref> In August 1946, Fargues saved the lives of Cousteau and [[Frédéric Dumas]] during their dive into the [[Fontaine-de-Vaucluse|Fountain of Vaucluse]]. On September 17, 1947, while attempting to set a new depth record, Maurice Fargues became the first diver to die using an [[Aqua-lung|aqualung]].<ref name="Matsen">{{cite book |author=Matsen, Brad |title=Jacques Cousteau: The Sea King |publisher=Pantheon Books |location=New York |year=2009 |pages=73, 76–79, 85 |isbn=978-0-375-42413-7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sowUaeKaJSMC&pg=PA73}}</ref>
== GRS and the Fountain of Vaucluse == In late 1945, Petty Officer Maurice Fargues joined the newly formed [[Groupe de Recherches Sous-marines|GRS]] (now called CEPHISMER), commanded by Philippe Tailliez, with Cousteau as its deputy commander and Dumas as civilian adviser and chief diver. Dumas trained Fargues and the GRS' other two new recruits, Petty Officers Jean-Paul Pinard and Guy Morandière, as Aqua-Lung divers.<ref name="Matsen"/> Maurice Fargues became commander of the diving tender ''VP 8'', a 21,6-meter (72-foot) twin-screw launch.<ref name="Cousteau">{{cite book|authorlink1=Jacques Cousteau|last1=Cousteau|first1=J. Y.|authorlink2=Frédéric Dumas|last2=Dumas|first2=Frédéric|year=1953|title=[[The Silent World (book)|The Silent World]]|location=New York|publisher=[[Harper & Brothers Publishers]]|lccn=52-5431}}</ref>
On August 27, 1946, the GRS dove into the Fountain of Vaucluse, a mysterious spring in the village of [[Vaucluse]], hoping to discover the secret of its yearly flooding. Maurice Fargues was the operation's surface commander, in charge of the guide rope which allowed divers to communicate with the surface. Tailliez and Morandière dove together first, but they were rapidly affected by a narcosis that almost compromised their return to the surface. When Cousteau and Dumas dove together, they suffered the same symptoms, and Tailliez and Fargues probably saved their lives by pulling them back up to the surface. It was later determined that [[carbon monoxide]] had unexpectedly contaminated the air in their cylinders.<ref name="Matsen"/><ref name="Cousteau"/><ref name="Burgess">{{cite book|last=Burgess|first=Robert F.|authorlink=Robert Forrest Burgess|title=The Cave Divers|year=1999|publisher=Aqua Quest Publications|location=[[Locust Valley, New York]]|pages=30–43|isbn=1-881652-11-4|lccn=96-39661|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LbwrLGZDMHMC&pg=PA30|chapter=Forty Fathoms to the Great Hall of Night}}</ref>
== Death == In September 1947, just before the "Salon Nautique" in Paris, Cousteau insisted to organize a series of deep diving attempts to determine the maximum depth a [[scuba diving|scuba]] diver could reach. On September 17, Maurice Fargues made the first deep diving attempt near the French Navy base at [[Toulon]].<ref name="Ecott">{{cite book |author=Ecott, Tim |title=Neutral Buoyancy: Adventures in a Liquid World |publisher=Atlantic Monthly Press |location=New York |year=2001 |pages=124–125 |isbn=0-87113-794-1 |lccn=2001018840 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5Dw7htaxwtUC&pg=PA124}}</ref> Maurice Fargues descended an anchor line with marker slates attached at 10 metres intervals, allowing him to sign his name on them to certify the depth he had reached, and periodically tugged on a safety line attached to his weight belt to let his colleague Frédéric Dumas on the surface know that he was alive. After three minutes, at a record-setting depth of {{convert|120|m|ft}}, Maurice Fargues stopped signalling. Philippe Tailliez ordered that he be pulled up, and Jean Pinard dove to meet him at 60 meters depth, only to discover that Fargues was unconscious, his mouthpiece hanging on his chest. Resuscitation attempts were continued for twelve hours, but Fargues was dead. [[Nitrogen narcosis]] or [[oxygen toxicity]] had caused him to lose his mouthpiece and drown.<ref name="Matsen"/><ref name="Cousteau"/><ref name="Ecott"/>
Fargues' scrawled signature on the slate at {{convert|120|m|ft}} confirmed his depth record. The GRS concluded that {{convert|90|m|ft}} was the maximum depth a diver using [[compressed air]] could reach.<ref name="Matsen"/><ref name="Cousteau"/> In the words of Jacques Cousteau: "Dumas and I owed our lives to Maurice Fargues, who had resurrected us from the death cave at Vaucluse. We will not be consoled that we were unable to save him."<ref name="Cousteau"/>
== Legacy == On September 17, 2007, the sixtieth anniversary of Fargues' death, a room was dedicated in his honor as the "Salle Maurice Fargues" at the [[Musée Frédéric-Dumas|Musée International de la Plongée Frédéric Dumas]] in [[Sanary-sur-Mer]], [[France]]. Fargues' children, Roselyne and Louis Fargues, were present at the ceremony.<ref name="Plaque"/><ref name="Musee">{{cite journal|url=http://www.plongeur.com/magazine/2007/09/19/musee-plongee-sous-marine-frederic-dumas/|title=Nouvelle salle au Musée International de la Plongée Frédéric Dumas|last=Charleux|first=Fabrice|journal=Plongeur.com|date=19 September 2007|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref> The room contains a plaque bearing a photograph of Fargues taken before his final dive and a reproduction of his final scrawled signature.<ref name="Plaque"/><ref name="Musee"/><ref name="Taillez">{{cite web|url=http://www.philippe.tailliez.net/article30.html|title=Naissance du GERS et des premiers plongeurs démineurs|date=1 December 2006|publisher=philippe.tailliez.net|accessdate=9 September 2013}}</ref>
On October 18, 2012, a conference {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NO_FfPdsX3U|title=Hommage à Maurice FARGUES ''La mer est calme, le ciel est clair''}} was given by Bernard Tailliez, son of Commander Philippe Tailliez, as part of a series of lectures entitled ''Les fils de Philippe Tailliez - 10 ans après'', organised by the ''[[Defence Historical Service|Service historique de la Défense]]'' at the ''Escale Castigneau'' ([[Military port of Toulon]]), honoring the memory of Philippe Tailliez, Petty Officer Maurice Fargues and the birth of the GRS. Fargues' children, Roselyne and Louis Fargues, were present at the ceremony.

revision.text:
'''Moral psychology''' is a field of study in both [[philosophy]] and [[psychology]]. Some use the term "moral psychology" relatively narrowly to refer to the study of [[moral development]].<ref>See, for example, {{cite book|title=Moral Psychology|last=Lapsley|first=Daniel K.|date=1996|publisher=Westview Press|year=|isbn=978-0-8133-3032-7|series=Developmental psychology series|location=Boulder, Colorado|pages=}}</ref> However, others tend to use the term more broadly to include any topics at the intersection of [[ethics]], psychology, and [[philosophy of mind]].<ref>{{cite | last=Doris | first=John | last2=Stich | first2= Stephen | year=2008 | title=Moral Psychology: Empirical Approaches | journal=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy | editor-first= Edward N. | editor-last=Zalta | url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-psych-emp/ | ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | editor-last=Jackson | editor-first=Frank | editor-last2=Smith | editor-first2=Michael | last=Wallace | first=R. Jay | title=The Oxford Handbook of Contemporary Philosophy | chapter=Moral Psychology | date=November 29, 2007 | pages=86–113 | chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H4sIErz7KUcC&pg=PA86 | publisher=OUP Oxford | isbn=978-0-19-923476-9 | quote=Moral psychology is the study of morality in its psychological dimensions}}</ref> Some of the main topics of the field are moral judgment, [[moral reasoning]], moral sensitivity, [[moral responsibility]], moral motivation, moral identity, moral action, [[moral development]], [[moral diversity]], [[moral character]] (especially as related to [[virtue ethics]]), [[altruism]], [[psychological egoism]], [[moral luck]], moral forecasting, moral emotion, [[affective forecasting]], and moral disagreement.{{sfn|Doris|Stich|2008|loc=§1}}<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Teper|first1=R.|last2=Inzlicht|first2=M.|last3=Page-Gould|first3=E.|date=|year=2011|title=Are we more moral than we think?: Exploring the role of affect in moral behavior and moral forecasting|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.1033.5192&rep=rep1&type=pdf|journal=Psychological Science|volume=22|issue=4|pages=553–558|doi=10.1177/0956797611402513|pmid=21415242|via=}}</ref>
A moral act is a type of behavior that refers has either a moral or immoral consequence. In many cultures, a moral act refers to an act that entails [[free will]], purity, [[liberty]], [[honesty]], and meaning, whereas an immoral act refers to an act that entails [[corruption]] and fraudulence.
Some psychologists that have worked in the field are: [[Jean Piaget]], [[Lawrence Kohlberg]], [[Carol Gilligan]], [[Elliot Turiel]], [[Jonathan Haidt]], [[Linda Skitka]], Leland Saunders, [[Marc Hauser]], [[Daniel Batson|C. Daniel Batson]], [[Jean Decety]], [[Joshua Greene (psychologist)|Joshua Greene]], A. Peter McGraw, [[Philip Tetlock]], [[Darcia Narvaez]], Tobias Krettenauer, Liane Young, Daniel Hart, Suzanne Fegley, and Fiery Cushman. Philosophers that have worked in the field include [[Stephen Stich]], John Doris, [[Joshua Knobe]], John Mikhail, [[Shaun Nichols]], [[Thomas Nagel]], Robert C. Roberts, [[Jesse Prinz]], [[Michael A. Smith (philosopher)|Michael Smith]], and [[R. Jay Wallace]].
== Background ==
Moral psychology began with early philosophers such as [[Aristotle]], [[Plato]], and [[Socrates]]. They believed that "to know the good is to do the good". They analyzed the ways in which people make decisions with regards to moral identity. As the field of psychology began to divide away from philosophy, moral psychology expanded to include [[risk perception]] and moralization, [[Medical ethics|morality with regards to medical practices]], concepts of [[self-worth]], and the role of emotions when analyzing one's moral identity. In most introductory psychology courses, students learn about moral psychology by studying the psychologist [[Lawrence Kohlberg]],<ref>{{cite book|title=Handbook of Socialization Theory and Research|last=Kohlberg|first=L.|date=1969|publisher=Rand McNally|editor-last=Goslin|editor-first=David|location=Chicago|pages=347–480|chapter=Stage and sequence: The cognitive development approach to socialization}}</ref> who introduced the [[Kohlberg's stages of moral development|moral development theory]] in 1969. This theory was built on [[Jean Piaget|Piaget]]'s observation that children develop intuitions about justice that they can later articulate. The increasing sophistication of articulation of reasoning is a sign of development. Moral cognitive development centered around justice and guided moral action increase with development, resulting in a postconventional thinker that can "do no other" than what is reasoned to be the most moral action. But researchers using the Kohlberg model found a gap between what people said was most moral and actions they took. Today, some psychologists and students{{Where|date=February 2018}} alike rely on Augusto Blasi's self-model{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} that link ideas of moral judgment and action through moral commitment. Those with moral goals central to the self-concept are more likely to take moral action, as they feel a greater obligation to do so. Those who are motivated will attain a unique moral identity.<ref name="Hardy, S. A. 2011">{{cite journal|last1=Hardy|first1=S. A.|last2=Carlo|first2=G.|date=|year=2011|title=Moral identity: What is it, how does it develop, and is it linked to moral action?|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Gustavo_Carlo/publication/229948988_Moral_Identity_What_Is_It_How_Does_It_Develop_and_Is_It_Linked_to_Moral_Action/links/59dbf9a9458515e9ab4526fc/Moral-Identity-What-Is-It-How-Does-It-Develop-and-Is-It-Linked-to-Moral-Action.pdf|journal=Child Development Perspectives|volume=5|issue=3|pages=212–218|doi=10.1111/j.1750-8606.2011.00189.x|via=}}</ref>
==History== Historically, early philosophers such as Aristotle and Plato engaged in both [[empirical research]] and ''[[A priori and a posteriori|a priori]]'' [[conceptual analysis]] about the ways in which people make decisions about issues that raise moral concerns. With the development of psychology as a discipline separate from philosophy, it was natural for psychologists to continue pursuing work in moral psychology, and much of the empirical research of the 20th century in this area was completed by academics working in psychology departments.
Today, moral psychology is a thriving area of research in both philosophy and psychology, even at an [[interdisciplinary]] level.<ref>Doris & Stich (2008), §1.</ref> For example, the psychologist Lawrence Kohlberg questioned boys and young men about their thought processes when they were faced with a [[moral dilemma]]<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Kohlberg|first=Lawrence|title=The development of modes of moral thinking and choice in the years 10 to 16.|date=1958|degree=PhD|location=Chicago|oclc=1165315}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{cite book|title=The Measurement of Moral Judgment|last1=Colby|first1=Anne|last2=Kohlberg|first2=Lawrence|date=1987|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=978-0-521-32565-3|series=Standard Issue Scoring Manual|volume=2|location=Cambridge|pages=}}</ref> producing one of many very useful empirical studies in the area of moral psychology. As another example, the philosopher [[Joshua Knobe]] recently{{When|date=February 2018}} completed an [[empirical study]] on how the way in which an ethical problem is phrased dramatically affects an individual's intuitions about the proper moral response to the problem.{{citation needed|date=September 2008}} More conceptually focused research has been completed by researchers such as John Doris. Doris discusses the way in which [[Social psychology|social psychological]] experiments—such as the [[Stanford prison experiment]]s involving the idea of [[Situationism (psychology)|situationism]]—call into question a key component in [[virtue ethics]]: the idea that individuals have a single, environment-independent moral character.<ref>{{cite book|title=Lack of Character: Personality and Moral Behavior|last=Doris|first=John M.|date=2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=978-1-316-02549-9|location=|pages=}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=February 2018}} As a further example, [[Shaun Nichols]] (2004) examines how empirical data on psychopathology suggests that [[moral rationalism]] is false.<ref>{{cite book|title=Sentimental Rules: On the Natural Foundations of Moral Judgment|last=Nichols|first=Shaun|date=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=978-0-19-988347-9|location=|pages=}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=February 2018}}
== Key Theorists in Moral Psychology == [[Lawrence Kohlberg]] was one of the forerunners in the development of an empirical measure for moral reasoning. He proposed [[Lawrence Kohlberg's stages of moral development|six stages]] broken into 3 categories of moral reasoning that, he believed to be universal to all people in all cultures<ref>{{Citation|last=Kohlberg|first=Lawrence|title=1. Stages of moral development as a basis for moral education|date=1971-01-31|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.3138/9781442656758-004|work=Moral Education|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=9781442656758|access-date=2018-09-23}}</ref>. Throughout his career, he focused on narrowing his focus deeper and deeper into a bedrock of human moral reasoning. one of his famous accomplishments was the development of a moral dilemma known as ''The [[Heinz dilemma|Heinz Dilemma]]'' in which the reader would follow a character, Heinz, through a dilemma to either steal a drug to possibly save his wife from death by cancer, or not steal the drug. Any participants were asked to respond and provide their reasoning for why or why not Heinz should steal the drug for his wife; in so answering, and given their reasoning about why Heinz should or should not steal it, Kohlberg could reliably come to a rational and empirical conclusion about the moral stage the participant was in.
==Measures== Philosophers and psychologists have created structured interviews and surveys as a means to study moral psychology and its development.
===Interview techniques=== Since at least 1894, philosophers and psychologists attempted to empirically evaluate the morality of an individual, especially attempting to distinguish adults from children in terms of their judgment, but the efforts failed because they "attempted to quantify how much morality an individual had—a notably contentious idea—rather than understand the individual's psychological representation of morality".<ref name="Wendorf2001">{{cite journal|last=Wendorf|first=Craig A|date=|year=2001|title=History of American morality research, 1894–1932|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Craig_Wendorf/publication/247411256_History_of_American_morality_research_1894-1932/links/585d17bc08ae6eb8719ff203/History-of-American-morality-research-1894-1932.pdf|journal=History of Psychology|volume=4|issue=3|pages=272–288|doi=10.1037/1093-4510.4.3.272|via=}}</ref> Lawrence Kohlberg addressed that difficulty in 1963 by modeling evaluative diversity as reflecting a series of developmental stages (à la Jean Piaget). [[Lawrence Kohlberg's stages of moral development]] are:<ref name="higheststage">{{cite journal | last=Kohlberg | first=Lawrence | title=The Claim to Moral Adequacy of a Highest Stage of Moral Judgment | journal=Journal of Philosophy | volume=70 | year=1973 | pages=630–646 | doi=10.2307/2025030 | issue=18 | jstor=2025030 }}</ref> # Obedience and punishment orientation # Self-interest orientation # Interpersonal accord and conformity # Authority and social-order maintaining orientation # Social contract orientation # Universal ethical principles
Stages 1 and 2 are combined into a single stage labeled "pre-conventional", and stages 5 and 6 are combined into a single stage labeled "post-conventional" for the same reason; psychologists can consistently categorize subjects into the resulting four stages using the "Moral Judgement Interview" which asks subjects why they endorse the answers they do to a standard set of moral dilemmas.<ref name=":2" />
Rather than confirm the existence of a single highest stage, Larry Walker's [[cluster analysis]] of a wide variety of interview and survey variables for moral exemplars found three types: the "caring" or "communal" cluster was strongly relational and generative, the "deliberative" cluster had sophisticated [[epistemic]] and moral reasoning, and the "brave" or "ordinary" cluster was less distinguished by personality.<ref name="Walker2010">{{cite journal | last=Walker | first=Lawrence J. | last2=Frimer | first2=Jeremy A. | last3=Dunlop | first3=William L. | title=Varieties of moral personality: beyond the banality of heroism | journal=Journal of Personality | volume=78 | year=2010 | pages=907–942 | issue=3| pmid=20573130 | doi=10.1111/j.1467-6494.2010.00637.x}}</ref>
===Survey instruments=== Between 1910 and 1930, in the United States and Europe, several morality tests were developed to classify subjects as fit or unfit to make moral judgments.<ref name=Wendorf2001/><ref name="Verplaetse2008">{{cite journal | last=Verplaetse | first=Jan | title=Measuring the moral sense: morality tests in continental Europe between 1910 and 1930 | journal= Paedagogica Historica | volume=44 | issue=3 | year=2008 | pages=265–286 | doi=10.1080/00309230701722721}}</ref> Test-takers would classify or rank standardized lists of personality traits, hypothetical actions, or pictures of hypothetical scenes. As early as 1926, catalogs of personality tests included sections specifically for morality tests, though critics persuasively argued that they merely measured awareness of social expectations.<ref name=":5">{{cite book|title=The Philosophy of Moral Development|last=Kohlberg|first=Lawrence|date=1981|publisher=Harper & Row|isbn=978-0-06-064760-5|series=Essays on Moral Developent|volume=1|location=San Francisco|oclc=7307342}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=February 2018}}
Meanwhile, Kohlberg inspired a new wave of morality tests. The [[Defining Issues Test]] (dubbed "Neo-Kohlbergian" by its constituents) scores relative preference for post-conventional justifications,<ref>{{cite book|title=Development in Judging Moral Issues|last=Rest|first=James R.|date=1979|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|isbn=978-0-8166-0891-1|location=Minneapolis}}</ref> and the Moral Judgment Test scores consistency of one's preferred justifications.<ref name="Lind1978">{{cite book|title=Sozialisation und Moral|last=Lind|first=Georg|publisher=Beltz|year=1978|isbn=9783407511348|editor-last=Portele|editor-first=G.|location=Weinheim|pages=171–201|language=German|trans-title=Socialization and Morality|chapter=Wie misst man moralisches Urteil? Probleme und alternative Möglichkeiten der Messung eines komplexen Konstrukts|trans-chapter=How do you measure moral judgment? Problems and alternative ways of measuring a complex construct|oclc=715635639}}</ref> Both treat evaluative ability as similar to [[IQ]] (hence the single score), allowing categorization by high score vs. low score.
The [[Jonathan Haidt#Moral Foundations Theory|Moral Foundations Questionnaire]] is based on moral intuitions consistent across cultures: care/harm, fairness/cheating, loyalty/betrayal, authority/subversion, and sanctity/degradation (liberty/oppression may be added). The questions ask respondents to rate what they consider morally relevant post-consciously (i.e. this is not a behavioral measure). The purpose of the questionnaire is to measure the degree to which people rely upon different sets of moral intuitions (which may coexist), rather than to categorize decision-makers, but the first two foundations cluster together with liberal political orientation and the latter three cluster with conservative political orientation.<ref name="Graham2009">{{cite journal|last=Graham|first=Jesse|last2=Haidt|first2=Jonathan|last3=Nosek|first3=Brian A.|date=|year=2009|title=Liberals and conservatives rely on different sets of moral foundations|url=http://projectimplicit.net/nosek/papers/GHN2009.pdf|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=96|issue=5|pages=1029–1046|doi=10.1037/a0015141|pmid=19379034|via=}}</ref><ref name="Graham2013">{{cite journal | last1=Graham | first1=J. | last2=Haidt | first2=J.| last3=Koleva | first3=S.| last4=Motyl | first4=M.| last5=Iyer | first5=R.| last6=Wojcik | first6=S.| last7=Ditto | first7=P.H.| title=Moral Foundations Theory: The pragmatic validity of moral pluralism | journal=Advances in Experimental Social Psychology | volume=47 | year=2013 | pages=55–130 | url=http://www-bcf.usc.edu/~jessegra/papers/GHKMIWD.inpress.MFT.AESP.pdf | format=PDF | doi=10.1016/b978-0-12-407236-7.00002-4}}</ref>
The Moral DNA survey by [[Roger Steare]] asks respondents to rank their virtues, then divides respondents by three virtue clusters: obedience, care, and reason. The survey was developed for use in business settings, especially to raise awareness of ways perceived [[workplace discrimination]] diminishes effective evaluative diversity.<ref>{{cite book|title=Ethicability: (n) How to Decide What's Right and Find the Courage to Do It|last1=Steare|first1=Roger|last2=Roger Steare Consulting Limited|date=2006|publisher=Roger Steare Consulting Limited|year=|isbn=978-0-9552369-0-7|location=London|pages=|oclc=70173013}}</ref>
In 1999, some of Kohlberg's measures were tested when Anne Colby and William Damon published a study in which the development of extraordinary moral development was examined in the lives of moral exemplars. In order to specifically show how people may develop exceptional moral commitments, the researchers focused on the two stories of women seen as moral exemplars. They came from different backgrounds and yet had similar moral development over the course of their lives. After finding these participants that exhibited high levels of moral commitment in their everyday behavior, the researchers utilized the moral judgement interview (MJI) to compare the 23 exemplars (including the two women) with a more ordinary group of people. The researchers also put the 23 exemplars through two standard dilemmas to assess what level they were on in Kohlberg's stages. The intention was to learn more about moral exemplars and to examine the strengths and weaknesses of the Kohlberg measure. It was found that the MJI scores were not clustered at the high end of Kohlberg's scale, they ranged from stage 3 to stage 5. Half landed at the conventional level (stages 3, 3/4, and 4) and the other half landed at the postconventional level (stages 4/5 and 5). Compared to the general population, the scores of the moral exemplars may be somewhat higher than those of groups not selected for outstanding moral behaviour. Researchers noted that the "moral judgement scores are clearly related to subjects' educational attainment in this study". Among the participants that had attained college education or above, there was no difference in moral judgement scores between genders. The study noted that although the exemplars' scores may have been higher than those of nonexemplars, it is also clear that one is not required to score at Kohlberg's highest stages in order to exhibit high degrees of moral commitment and exemplary behaviour.<ref name=":2" /> Apart from their scores, it was found that the 23 participating moral exemplars described three similar themes within all of their moral developments: certainty, positivity, and the unity of self and moral goals. The unity between self and moral goals was highlighted as the most important theme as it is what truly sets the exemplars apart from the 'ordinary' people. It was discovered that the moral exemplars see their morality as a part of their sense of identity and sense of self, not as a conscious choice or chore. Also, the moral exemplars showed a much broader range of moral concern than did the ordinary people and go beyond the normal acts of daily moral engagements. For example, the moral exemplars would feed their own children, but then go farther and fight to end world hunger on a global scale as well. In order to encourage this strong sense of moral development in children and adolescents, it is recommended to encourage a sense of empowerment and to also show a positive and optimistic approach to life.
==Theories==
===Moral identity=== Empirical studies show that reasoning and emotion only moderately predicted moral action. Scholars, such as Blasi, began proposing identity as a motivating factor in moral motivation.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Blasi|first=Augusto|date=1980|title=Bridging moral cognition and moral action: A critical review of the literature.|journal=Psychological Bulletin|volume=88|issue=1|pages=1–45|doi=10.1037/0033-2909.88.1.1|issn=0033-2909}}</ref> Blasi proposed the self model of moral functioning, which described the effects of the judgment of responsibility to perform a moral action, one's sense of moral identity, and the desire for self-consistency on moral action. Blasi also elaborates on the structure of identity and its connection to morality. According to Blasi, there are two aspects that form identity. One of the aspects focuses on the specific contents that make up the self (objective identity content), which include moral ideals. The second refers to the ways in which identity is subjectively experienced (subjective identity experience). As the subjective side of identity matures, the objective side tends to lean towards internal contents like values, beliefs, and goals, rather than external identity contents like physical aspects, behaviors, and relationships. A mature subjective identity yearns for a greater sense of self-consistency. Therefore, identity would serve as a motivation for moral action. Studies of moral exemplars have shown that exemplary moral action often results from the intertwining of personal goals and desires with moral goals, and studies on moral behavior also show a correlation between moral identity and action. S. Hardy and G. Carlo raise critical questions about Blasi's model as well, and propose that researchers should seek to better operationalize and measure moral identity and apply findings to moral education and intervention programs.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hardy | first1 = S. A. | last2 = Carlo | first2 = G. | year = 2005 | title = Identity as a source of moral motivation | url = | journal = Human Development | volume = 48 | issue = | pages = 232–256 | doi=10.1159/000086859}}</ref>
Anne Colby and William Damon suggest that one's moral identity is formed through that individual's synchronization of their personal and moral [[goal]]s. This unity of their self and morality is what distinguishes them from non-exemplars and in turn makes them exceptional.<ref>{{cite book|title=Morality in Everyday Life: Developmental Perspectives|last1=Colby|first1=Anne|last2=Damon|first2=William|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1999|isbn=978-0-521-66586-5|editor-last=Killen|editor-first=Melanie|location=|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=5gp4S52D5koC&pg=PA362 362]|chapter=The Development of Extraordinary Moral Commitment|editor-last2=Hart|editor-first2=Daniel|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=5gp4S52D5koC&pg=PA342}}</ref> Colby and Damon studied moral identity through the narratives of civil rights activist [[Virginia Foster Durr]] and Suzie Valadez, who provided services for the poor, whose behavior, actions, and life's works were considered to be morally exemplary by their communities and those with whom they came in contact. Some common characteristics that these moral exemplars possess are certainty, positivity (e.g. enjoyment of work, and optimism), and unity of self and moral goals.{{Sfn|Colby|Damon|1999|p=|pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=5gp4S52D5koC&pg=PA361 361–362]}} The research suggests that a "transformation of goals" takes place during the evolution of one's moral identity and development and therefore is not an exercise of self-sacrifice but rather one done with great joy; moral exemplars see their personal goals and moral goals as synonymous. This transformation is not always a deliberate process and is most often a gradual process, but can also be rapidly set off by a triggering event.{{Sfn|Colby|Damon|1999|p=354}} Triggering events can be anything from a powerful moment in a movie to a [[Trauma (psychology)|traumatic life event]], or as in the case of Suzie Valadez, the perception of a [[Vision (spirituality)|vision from God]]. In many of the moral exemplars interviewed, the triggering events and goal transformation did not take place until their 40s. Moral exemplars are said to have the same concerns and commitments as other moral people but to a greater degree, "extensions in scope, intensity and breadth".{{Sfn|Colby|Damon|1999|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=5gp4S52D5koC&pg=PA364 364]}} Furthermore, exemplars possess the ability to be open to new ideas and experiences, also known as an "active receptiveness"{{Sfn|Colby|Damon|1999|p=350}} to things exterior to themselves.
Daniel Hart conducted a study to see how adolescents who engaged in exemplary levels of prosocial behavior viewed themselves. To empirically study self-concept, he used four different conceptual models to illustrate the concept of self: Self-Concept as Content, Self-Concept as Semantic Space, Self-Concept as Hierarchy of Selves, and Self-Concept as Theory. The findings suggested that adolescent caring exemplars formulated their self-concept differently from comparable peers. In a hierarchy of selves model, exemplars were shown to incorporate their "ideal self" into their "actual self". Among the exemplar group there was more incorporation of parental representations with the "actual self". Conversely, there was less incorporation of representations of their best friend or the self expected by the best friend. It is theorized that this is because adolescents are less likely to pick a best friend who is a "goody-goody" and deeply involved in service, as well as exemplars possibly having to give up peer expectations in order to engage in service. In a Self-Concept as Theory model, exemplars were most commonly at level 4, a level of self-theory uncommonly reached by adolescents, but common among exemplars.They were also more likely to emphasize academic goals and moral typical activities. There were no significant differences between the exemplars and the control group concerning moral knowledge. On a [[semantic space]] analysis, the moral exemplars tended to view their actual self as more integrated with their ideal and expected self.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hart|first1=D.|last2=Fegley|first2=S.|date=|year=1995|title=Prosocial behavior and caring in adolescence: Relations to self-understanding and social judgment|url=http://www.uca.edu.ar/uca/common/grupo18/files/hartfegley1995CD.pdf|journal=Child Development|volume=66|issue=5|pages=1346–1359|doi=10.2307/1131651|pmid=7555220|via=}}</ref>
[[David Wong (philosopher)|David Wong]] proposes that we think of cultures in an analogy to a conversation, there are people with different beliefs, values, and norms that can voice their opinion loudly or quietly, but over the course of time these factors can change. A moral culture can provide other members with a kind of "language" where there is plenty of room for different "dialects", this allows moral identities to be established and voiced more. Opposing ideas can create conflict between those who are close to us, such as family and friends, and strangers. This can bring a greater risk of trying to decide the best course of action in which either party will be affected by it. In essence the notion of Wong's theory is that in order to define our true morality it ultimately comes down to acceptance and being able to accommodate within and between cultures around the world. He also believes that the concept of culture as conversation will help reduce the problems with boundaries between cultures, reconcile the autonomy with the cultural aspect of moral identity and call into question the understanding of healthy and well developed moral identity.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Narvaez |first1=Darcia |last2=Lapsley |first2=Daniel K. |title=Personality, Identity, and Character: Explorations in Moral Psychology |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-521-89507-1 |pages=79–105 |chapter=Chapter 4}}</ref>
According to Blasi's theory on [[moral character]], moral character is identified by the person's set of the morality of virtues and vices. He theorized [[Volition (psychology)|willpower]], moral desires, and integrity have the capability for a person to act morally by the hierarchical order of virtues. He believed that the "highest" and complex of virtues are expressed by willpower while the "lowest" and simplistic of virtues are expressed integrity. He essentially stated that to have the lower virtues, one must have one or more of the higher virtues. The end goals of moral development identity are to establish and act upon core goals, as well as and use one's strengths to make a difference.<ref>{{cite book|title=Character Psychology and Character Education|last=Blasi|first=Augusto|publisher=University of Notre Dame Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-268-03371-2|editor-last=Lapsley|editor-first=Daniel|location=Notre Dame, Indiana|pages=67–100|chapter=Moral character: A psychological approach|editor-last2=Power|editor-first2=F.}}</ref>
===Moral self===
A "moral self" is fostered by mutually-responsive [[Parenting styles|parenting]] in childhood. Children with responsive parents develop more empathy, prosociality, a moral self and conscience.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kochanska|first=Grazyna|date=2002|title=Mutually Responsive Orientation Between Mothers and Their Young Children: A Context for the Early Development of Conscience|url=|journal=Current Directions in Psychological Science|volume=11|issue=6|pages=191–195|doi=10.1111/1467-8721.00198|issn=0963-7214|via=}}</ref> Darcia Narvazes describes the neurobiological and social elements of early experience and their effects on moral capacities.<ref>{{cite book|title=Neurobiology and the Development of Human Morality: Evolution, Culture, and Wisdom (Norton Series on Interpersonal Neurobiology)|last=Narvaez|first=Darcia|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|year=2014|isbn=978-0-393-70967-4}}</ref>
The moral self results when people integrate moral values into their self-concept.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Krettenauer | first1 = T | year = 2011 | title = The dual moral self: Moral centrality and internal moral motivation | url = | journal = The Journal of Genetic Psychology | volume = 172 | issue = | pages = 309–328 | doi = 10.1080/00221325.2010.538451 }}</ref> Research on the moral self has mostly focused on adolescence as a critical time period for the integration of self and morality<ref>{{cite book|title=Self-Regulation and Autonomy|last=Krettenauer|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2013|isbn=978-1-107-02369-7|editor-last=Sokol|editor-first=Bryan|pages=115–140|chapter=Revisiting the moral self construct: Developmental perspectives on moral selfhood|editor-last2=Grouzet|editor-first2=Frederick|editor-last3=Müller|editor-first3=Ulrich|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=CVRsAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA115}}</ref> (i.e. self and morality are traditionally seen as separate constructs that become integrated in adolescence.<ref>See, for example, {{cite book|title=Self-Understanding in Childhood and Adolescence|last1=Damon|first1=William|last2=Hart|first2=Daniel|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1988|isbn=978-0-521-30791-8}}</ref> However, the moral self may be established around age 2–3 years.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Emde|first1=R.|last2=Biringen|first2=Z.|last3=Clyman|first3=R.|last4=Oppenheim|first4=D.|date=|year=1991|title=The moral self of infancy: Affective core and procedural knowledge|url=http://ericastiftelsen.se/doc/EPU_13.16/Emde_Clyman_1991.pdf|journal=Developmental Review|volume=11|issue=|pages=251–270|doi=10.1016/0273-2297(91)90013-e|via=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kochanska | first1 = G | year = 2002 | title = Committed compliance, moral self, and internalization: A mediational model | url = | journal = Developmental Psychology | volume = 38 | issue = | pages = 339–351 | doi = 10.1037/0012-1649.38.3.339 }}</ref> In fact, children as young as 5 years-old are able to consistently identify themselves as having certain moral behavioral preferences.<ref name="Krettenauer, T. 2013">{{cite journal|last1=Krettenauer|first1=T.|last2=Campbell|first2=S.|last3=Hertz|first3=S.|date=|year=2013|title=Moral emotions and the development of the moral self in childhood|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Tobias_Krettenauer/publication/271672618_Moral_emotions_and_the_development_of_the_moral_self_in_childhood/links/5540fc170cf2718618dc965b/Moral-emotions-and-the-development-of-the-moral-self-in-childhood.pdf|journal=European Journal of Developmental Psychology|volume=10|issue=|pages=159–173|doi=10.1080/17405629.2012.762750|via=}}</ref> Children's moral self is also increasingly predictive of moral emotions with age.<ref
