of a Project 629A (Golf II) ballistic missile submarine]] '''''K-129''''' was a Project 629A ([[NATO reporting name]] [[Golf-class submarine|Golf II]]) diesel-electric powered submarine of the [[Soviet Pacific Fleet]], one of six [[Project 629]] strategic ballistic missile submarines attached to the 15th Submarine Squadron based at Rybachiy Naval Base, [[Kamchatka]], commanded by Rear Admiral Rudolf A. Golosov. In January 1968, the 15th Submarine Squadron was part of the 29th Ballistic Missile Division at Rybachiy, commanded by Admiral Viktor A. Dygalo. ''K-129''{{'}}s commander was Captain First Rank V.I. Kobzar. ''K-129'' carried [[hull number]] 722 on her final deployment during which she sank on 8 March 1968. It was one of four mysterious submarine disappearances in 1968; the others being the Israeli submarine {{Ship|INS|Dakar}}, the {{Ship|French submarine|Minerve|S647|6}} and the U.S. submarine {{USS|Scorpion|SSN-589|6}}. The Soviet Navy deployed a huge flotilla of ships to search for her but never found her wreck. The United States attempted to recover the boat in 1974 in a secret [[Cold War]]-era effort named [[Project Azorian]]. The vessel's position {{convert|16000|ft|km|order=flip}} below the surface was the greatest depth from which an attempt had been made to raise a ship. The [[cover up|cover story]] used was that the salvage vessel was engaged in commercial [[manganese nodule]] mining. Only part of the submarine was recovered. [[File:K-129 Incident Map.tif|alt=Sinking of K-129 detailed on a Map|thumb|448x448px|Map of the sinking of ''K-129'']] ==Sinking== ''K-129'', having completed two 70-day ballistic-missile combat patrols in 1967, was tasked with her third patrol in February 1968, with an expected completion date of 5 May 1968. Upon departure on 24 February, ''K-129'' reached deep water, conducted its test dive, returned to the surface to report by radio that all was well, and proceeded on patrol. No further communication was received from ''K-129'', despite normal radio check-ins expected when the submarine crossed the 180th meridian, and when it arrived at its patrol area. By mid-March, Soviet naval authorities in [[Kamchatka]] became concerned that ''K-129'' had missed two consecutive radio check-ins. First, ''K-129'' was instructed by normal fleet broadcast to break radio silence and contact headquarters; later and more urgent communications all went unanswered. Soviet naval headquarters declared ''K-129'' "missing" by the third week of March and organized an air, surface, and sub-surface search-and-rescue effort in the North Pacific from Kamchatka and [[Vladivostok]]. This Soviet deployment in the Pacific was analysed by U.S. intelligence as probably in reaction to a submarine loss. U.S. [[SOSUS]] Naval Facilities ([[Naval Facilities Engineering Command|NAVFACs]]) in the North Pacific were alerted and requested to review recent acoustic records to identify any possible associated signal. Several SOSUS arrays recorded a possibly related event on 8 March 1968, and upon examination produced sufficient triangulation by lines-of-bearing to provide the U.S. Navy with a [[Locus (mathematics)|locus]] for the probable wreck site. One source characterized the acoustic signal as "an isolated, single sound of an explosion or implosion, 'a good-sized bang'."Craven, 2001{{rp|205}} The acoustic event was reported to have originated near 40 N, 180th longitude. Soviet search efforts, lacking the equivalent of the U.S. SOSUS system, were unable to locate ''K-129'', and eventually Soviet naval activity in the North Pacific returned to normal. ''K-129'' was subsequently declared lost with all hands. American intelligence resources, with the aid of SOSUS triangulation, would later locate the ''K-129'' wreck, photograph it ''[[in situ]]'' at its {{convert|16000|ft|m|-2|adj=on|order=flip}} depth, and partially salvage it several years later. ==Discovery and salvage: Project Azorian== {{main|Project Azorian}} The wreck of ''K-129'' was identified by {{USS|Halibut|SSGN-587|6}} northwest of [[Oahu]] at an approximate depth of {{convert|16000|ft|m|-2|order=flip}} on 20 August 1968."K-129", in ''Historical Dictionary of International Intelligence'', by Nigel West (Rowman & Littlefield, 2015) p183 It was surveyed in detail over the next three weeks by ''Halibut'' – reportedly with over 20,000 close-up photos – and later also possibly by the [[bathyscaphe]] {{ship|Bathyscaphe|Trieste II||2}}. Given a unique opportunity to recover a Soviet [[R-21 (missile)|SS-N-5 Serb]] nuclear missile without the knowledge of the Soviet Union, the ''K-129'' wreck came to the attention of U.S. national authorities. President Nixon authorized a salvage attempt after consideration by the Secretary of Defense and the White House. To ensure the salvage attempt remained "[[Black operation|black]]" (''i.e.'' clandestine and secret) the [[CIA]], rather than the Navy, was tasked to conduct the operation. ''[[GSF Explorer|Hughes Glomar Explorer]]'' was designed and built under CIA contract solely for the purpose of conducting a clandestine salvage of ''K-129''. The salvage operation, named [[Project Azorian]], would be one of the most expensive and deepest secrets of the Cold War. ===Leak and widespread media attention=== [[Seymour Hersh]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' uncovered some of the details of Project Azorian in 1974, but was kept from publication by the action of the [[Director of Central Intelligence]], [[William Colby]]. Months after the salvage operation was completed, in February 1975, the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' ran a brief story regarding the CIA operation, which led ''The New York Times'' to release Hersh's story. [[Jack Anderson (columnist)|Jack Anderson]] continued the story on national television in March 1975.[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/nukevault/ebb305/doc01.pdf Project Azorian: The Story of the Hughes Glomar Explorer], a CIA declassified Secret Noforn document from the mid-1980s. The media called the operation Project Jennifer, which in 2010 was revealed to be incorrect, since Jennifer referred only to a security system which compartmentalised Azorian project data. ''Hughes Glomar Explorer'' was publicly believed to be mining [[manganese nodule]]s on the sea floor. Once the real purpose of Azorian was leaked to the media, however, the Soviet Union eventually found out about what happened. According to one account, in July–August 1974 ''Hughes Glomar Explorer'' grappled with and was able to lift the forward half of the wreck of ''K-129'', but as it was raised the claw suffered a critical failure resulting in the forward section breaking into two pieces with the all-important [[Submarine sail|sail]] area and centre section falling back to the ocean floor. Thus the centre sail area and the after portions of ''K-129'' were allegedly not recovered. What exactly was retrieved in the section that was recovered is classified Secret Noforn or [[Top Secret]], but the Soviets assumed that the United States recovered torpedoes with nuclear warheads, operations manuals, code books and coding machines. Another source (unofficial) states that the U.S. recovered the bow area, which contained two nuclear torpedoes,Polmar, 2004, Cold War Submarines{{rp|111}} but no cryptographic equipment nor code books.{{cite book|author1=Norman Polmar|author2=Kenneth J. Moore|title=Cold War Submarines: The Design and Construction of U.S. and Soviet Submarines|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U86giz-cluoC|year=2004|publisher=Potomac Books, Inc.|isbn=978-1-57488-594-1}} The United States announced that in the section they recovered were the bodies of six men.{{cite web |url=http://www.projectjennifer.at/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205063115/http://projectjennifer.at/ |archivedate=5 February 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Due to [[radioactive contamination]], the bodies were buried at sea in a steel chamber in September 1974, with full military honors about {{convert|90|nmi|km|0}} southwest of Hawaii. The videotape of that ceremony{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aJAJUJ41PBI|title=Burial At Sea of Soviet Submariners from Hughes Glomar Explorer|date=25 August 2014|publisher=Central Intelligence Agency|via=YouTube}} was given to [[Russia]] by U.S. Director of Central Intelligence [[Robert Gates]] when he visited Moscow in October 1992.{{rp|359}} The relatives of the crew members were eventually shown the video some years later. ===Continuing secrecy and official objections to full disclosure=== The ''K-129'' recovery has been stated to have been a failure, recovering only a small amount of insignificant parts of the submarine. The CIA argued in a [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] lawsuit, however, that the project had to be kept secret because any "[[Glomar response|official acknowledgment of involvement by U.S. Government agencies would disclose the nature and purpose of the program]]." {{cite court |litigants=Philippi v. CIA (Turner et al.) |vol=211 |reporter=US |opinion=App. D.D> 95 |pinpoint= |court=US Court of Appeals |date=25 June 1981 }} This response has entered the lexicon of legal jargon as ''the [[Glomar response]]'' or ''Glomarization''; "neither confirm nor deny". As of 2018 the files, photographs, videotapes and other documentary evidence remain closed to the public. A few pictures appeared in a 2010 documentary showing the ''K-129'' wreck: the bow and the sail, with the missile compartment heavily damaged showing only one missile tube left attached to the structure. ==Specific location== [[File:K129 HGE recoverysite.png|thumb|250px|Recovery site of ''K-129'']] The location of the wreck remains an official secret of the United States intelligence services. However, [[John P. Craven PhD, JD|Dr. John P. Craven]] points to a location nearly [[40th parallel north|40 degrees North]], and almost exactly on the [[180th meridian]]. CIA documents reveal that it sank "1,560 miles northwest of Hawaii," and that ''Hughes Glomar Explorer'' had to travel 3,008 miles from Long Beach, California, to reach the recovery site. The [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] states that two nuclear warheads from ''K-129'' were located in the Pacific 1,230 miles from Kamchatka at coordinates 40°6'N and 179°57'E at a depth of {{convert|6000|m}}, and lists them as recovered.{{cite web |url=http://www-pub.iaea.org/MTCD/publications/PDF/te_1242_prn.pdf |title=Inventory of accidents and losses at sea involving radioactive material, IAEA-TECDOC-1242, Appendix I.3 |format=pdf |date=September 2001 |publisher=[[International Atomic Energy Agency]] |accessdate=18 February 2010 }} {{cite web |url=http://docs.imo.org/Shared/Download.aspx?did=68104 |publisher=[[International Maritime Organization]] |date=15 July 2011 |title=LC 33/INF.5 Matters Related to the Management of Radioactive Wastes: Inventory of waste disposals, accidents and losses at sea involving radioactive materials |author=[[International Atomic Energy Agency]] |accessdate=11 September 2012 }}{{registration required |date=September 2012}} All three distances point to a location of {{coord|38|5||N|178|57||E}}, which is close to {{convert|600|nmi|km}} north of the [[Midway Atoll]]. The CIA gives {{convert|16440|and|16500|ft|order=flip}} for its approximate depth. ==Explaining the disaster== The official Soviet Navy hypothesis is that ''K-129'', while operating in [[Submarine snorkel|snorkel]] mode, slipped below its operating depth. Such an event, combined with a mechanical failure or improper crew reaction, can cause flooding sufficient to sink the boat.Podvig, 2001, Russian Strategic Nuclear Forces, p. 290 This account, however, has not been accepted by many, and four alternative theories have been advanced to explain the loss of ''K-129'': # A [[hydrogen]] explosion in the batteries while charging; # A collision with {{USS|Swordfish|SSN-579|6}}; # A missile explosion caused by a leaking missile door seal; # Intentional or unintentional scuttle by crew due to ''K-129'' violating normal operating procedures and/or departing from authorised operating areas. Reportedly, as many as 40 of the complement of 98 were new to the submarine for this deployment. ''K-129'' was approximately midway through standard shore leave/replenishment and repair when a new mission was tasked.Sewell (2005) ''Russian Strategic Nuclear Forces'', Center for Arms Control Studies, Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, edited by Pavel Podvig{{rp|156}} ===Hydrogen explosion=== [[Lead–acid batteries]] vent explosive hydrogen gas while charging. The hydrogen gas, if not properly vented, could have accumulated into an explosive concentration. Dr. John P. Craven, former chief scientist of the U.S. Navy's Special Projects Office and former head of the [[Deep Submergence Systems Project|DSSP]] and [[Deep Submergence Rescue Vehicle|DSRV]] programs, commented:
I have never seen or heard of a submarine disaster that was not accompanied by the notion that the battery blew up and started it all. [...] Naive investigators, examining the damage in salvaged battery compartments, invariably blame the sinking on battery explosions until they learn that any fully charged battery suddenly exposed to seawater will explode. It is an inevitable effect of a sinking and almost never a cause.{{rp|215}}
At least one American submarine, {{USS|Cochino|SS-345|6}}, on the other hand, was lost off Norway in 1949 due to a hydrogen explosion in the battery compartment. Most of ''Cochino's'' crew was rescued and the cause of her sinking is therefore known.Sontag and Drew, ''Blind Man's Bluff.'' New York: Public Affairs (1998) pp. 12–24 ===Collision with USS ''Swordfish''=== It was standard practice during the [[Cold War]] for [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] attack submarines to trail Soviet missile submarines as they departed their home ports and moved into the North Pacific or the North Atlantic Ocean.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-06-17/news/mn-12570_1/2 |title=Change in Soviets' Sub Tactics Tied to Spy Case: Material Reportedly Available to Walkers May Have Tipped Kremlin to Vessels' Vulnerability |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |first=Robert C. |last=Toth |accessdate=2 January 2011 |date=17 June 1985}} The collision hypothesis is the unofficial opinion of many [[Soviet Navy]] officers,Offley, Ed ''Scorpion Down: Sunk by the Soviets, Buried by the Pentagon'' (Paperback – 24 Mar 2008) and is officially denied by the U.S. Navy. According to U.S. Navy sources, {{USS|Swordfish|SSN-579|6}} put into [[Yokosuka, Japan]] on 17 March 1968, shortly after the disappearance of ''K-129'', and received emergency repairs to a bent periscope, reportedly caused by ice impacted during surfacing while conducting classified operations in the [[Sea of Japan]]. The {{USS|Pueblo|AGER-2|6}} seizure by the [[North Korea]]n government occurred in the Sea of Japan on 23 January 1968, and the U.S. Navy response to this incident included the deployment and maintenance of naval assets in the area off the eastern North Korean coast for some time thereafter. In response to Russian efforts to ascertain whether ''K-129'' had been lost due to damage resulting from a collision with a U.S. submarine, an official U.S. statement by Ambassador [[Malcolm Toon]] to a Russian delegation during a meeting in the Kremlin in August 1993 related: {{quote|At my request, U.S. naval intelligence searched the logs of all U.S. subs that were active in 1968. As a result, our director of naval intelligence has concluded that no U.S. sub was within {{convert|300|nmi|km|-1}} of your sub when it sank.Sewell (2005) ''Minutes of the Sixth Plenary Session'', USRJC, Moscow, 31 August 1993{{rp|262}} }} A news release in 2000 demonstrates that Russian suspicion and sensitivity concerning the collision possibility, and indeed their preference for such an explanation, remains active: {{quote |As recently as 1999, Russian government officials complained that Washington was covering up its involvement. One accused the Americans of acting like a "criminal that had been caught and now claimed that guilt must be proved," according to the notes of a U.S. participant in a November 1999 meeting on the topic.Robert Burns, AP, "Decades later, Russians press suspicion of U.S. role in sinking Soviet sub", 22 August 2000}} A picture of ''Swordfish'' on 17 March 1968 at its berth in Japan published in a Japanese newspaper showed only a bent periscope and a dented sail. A collision sufficient to breach the pressure hull of another submarine would have significantly damaged the sail. An unconfirmed report states that ''K-129'' was trailed from its home port [[Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky|Petropavlovsk]] by {{USS|Barb|SSN-596|6}}, which had been stationed off Petropavlovsk for an intelligence-gathering mission. USS ''Barb'', according to the report, had orders to attack ''K-129'' if the Russian submarine was preparing for a missile launch. The report further states that USS ''Barb'' witnessed the sinking of ''K-129'' but was not involved in it.{{cite web |url=http://www.mikekemble.com/misc/k129.html |title=The Amazing Story of the K129 – Project Azurian |first=Mike |last=Kemble |accessdate=1 November 2011 |date=May 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112043628/http://www.mikekemble.com/misc/k129.html |archivedate=12 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ===Missile explosion due to leaking hatch seal=== On 3 October 1986 the Soviet {{sclass2-|Yankee|submarine|0}} [[ballistic missile submarine]] {{ship|Soviet submarine|K-219||2}}, while on combat patrol in the Atlantic, suffered the explosion of a liquid-fuelled [[SS-N-6]] missile in one of its 16 missile tubes. The cause of the explosion was a leaking missile tube hatch seal. The leak allowed sea water to come into contact with residue of the missile's propellants, which caused a spontaneous fire resulting in an explosion first of the missile booster, then a subsequent explosion of the warhead detonator charge. In the case of the Yankee-class ballistic missile submarine, the missiles were located within the pressure hull and the explosion did not cause damage sufficient to immediately sink the boat. It did, however, cause extensive radioactive contamination throughout, requiring the submarine to surface and the evacuation of the crew to the weather deck, and later to a rescue vessel which had responded to the emergency. Subsequently, ''K-219'' sank into the [[Hatteras Abyss]] with the loss of four crewmen and rests at a depth of about {{convert|18000|ft|m|-2|order=flip}}. The Soviet Navy later claimed that the leak was caused by a collision with {{USS|Augusta|SSN-710|6}}. There are indicators suggesting ''K-129'' suffered a similar explosion in 1968. First, the radioactive contamination of the recovered bow section and the six crewmen of ''K-129'' by weapons grade plutonium indicates the explosion of the warhead detonator charge of one of the missiles, ''before'' the ship reached its [[crush depth]]. The report that the forward section was crushed and that charring in the bow section indicated [[dieseling]] from an implosion (or alternatively from a fire), would indicate that the explosion occurred while ''K-129'' was submerged and at depth. The report found in [[Blind Man's Bluff: The Untold Story of American Submarine Espionage|''Blind Man's Bluff'']] that the wreck revealed ''K-129'' with a {{convert|10|ft|m|0|adj=on|order=flip}} hole immediately abaft the [[Conning tower#Submarines|conning tower]] would support the theory of an explosion of one of the three missiles in the sail (possibly missile #3). Since ''K-129''{{'}}s missiles were housed in the sail, much less structural mass (compared to the Yankee-class) was available to contain such an explosion, and loss of depth control of the submarine would be instantaneous. ===''K-129'' off-course or out of area=== According to Dr. John P. Craven, ''K-129'' crossed the [[International Date Line]] at [[40th parallel north|latitude 40 north]], which was far south of her expected position:
When K-129 passed [[180th meridian|longitude 180]], it should have been farther north, at a [[45th parallel north|latitude of 45 degrees]], or more than three hundred miles away. If that was a navigational mistake it would be an error of historic proportions. Thus if the sub were not somewhere in the vicinity of where the Soviets supposed it to be, there would be a high probability, if not a certainty, that the submarine was a rogue, off on its own, in grave disobedience of its orders.{{rp|206}}
Craven does not explain why he eliminated the possibilities that ''K-129'' was proceeding to a newly assigned and officially approved patrol area, or using a new track to an established patrol area, nor why he concluded that ''K-129'' was acting in an abnormal or criminal manner for a Soviet strategic missile submarine. Craven also noted: {{quote |While the Russian submarine was presumed to be at sea, an oceanographic ship of the University of Hawaii was conducting research in the oceanic waters off [[Northwestern Hawaiian Islands|Hawaii's Leeward Islands]]. The researchers discovered a large slick on the surface of the ocean, collected a sample, and found that it was highly radioactive. They reported this to George Woolard, the director of the Hawaii Institute of Geophysical Research.{{rp|216}}}} Craven does not reconcile a sinking location at [[40th parallel north|40°N latitude]] with an oil slick hundreds of miles south of that latitude, nor does he reconcile the date and time of the sinking with the date and time of the recovery of radioactive oil by the oceanographic research ship.{{original research inline|date=May 2018}} Anatoliy Shtyrov (Анатолий Штыров), a former Deputy Chief of the Soviet Pacific Fleet intelligence, states that ''K-129'', whose normal patrol area was off the west coast of the United States, was sent on an unscheduled combat patrol in the eastern Pacific only 1.5 months after returning from its previous patrol. {{cite web |title=The tragedy of submarine K-129: Behind the scenes of operations "Jennifer" |language=Russian |url=http://flot.com/history/si58.htm |date=14 June 2008 |publisher=flot.com |first=Anatoliy |last=Shtyrov |accessdate=19 February 2010 }} Vladimir Evdasin (Владимир Евдасин), who from June 1960 to March 1961 served aboard ''K-129'', states that ''K-129'' was sent on a secret mission in response to the massive U.S. naval force build-up off the Korean coast after the [[USS Pueblo (AGER-2)|Pueblo incident]]. {{cite web |title=The Capture of the USS Pueblo and Its Effect on SIGINT Operations |url=http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB278/03.PDF |format=pdf |year=1992 |publisher=U.S. Cryptologic History, Special Series, Crisis Collection, Vol. 7, [[NSA]] |first=Robert E. |last=Newton |accessdate=19 February 2010 }} ''K-129''{{'}}s mission was in support of North Korea, which was an ally of the Soviet Union, and directed against U.S. naval operations, Pacific bases and U.S. maritime support lines to South-east Asia. {{cite web |title=K-129: How was it? |language=Russian |url=http://flot.com/history/branches/sub/k129.htm |date=14 June 2008 |publisher=flot.com |first=Vladimir |last=Evdasina |accessdate=20 February 2010 }}{{cite web |title=Has the "Fire!" Command Sounded in the Compartments of the Cold War? |url=http://rusnavy.com/history/events/scorpion.htm |publisher=rusnavy.com |accessdate=20 February 2010 }} ==Administrative inconsistencies== Russian President Boris Yeltsin posthumously awarded the Order of Valor to 98 sailors who died aboard ''K-129''. Some have pointed to this level of manning as anomalous, because the normal complement of a diesel-electric Golf-class Russian submarine was about 83.{{rp|156}} Boosting total submarine complement by almost 20% might tax the logistical capabilities of the submarine (reducing patrol duration), and could potentially hamper the operations of the boat. No explanation for this level of submarine manning has been provided by the Russian Navy. ==Alternative theories on Project Azorian== ''Red Star Rogue'' by Kenneth Sewell makes the claim that Project Azorian recovered virtually all of ''K-129'' from the ocean floor,{{rp|243}} and in fact "Despite an elaborate cover-up and the eventual claim the project had been a failure, most of ''K-129'' and the remains of the crew were, in fact, raised from the bottom of the Pacific and brought into the ''Glomar Explorer''".{{rp|22}} In August 1993, Ambassador [[Malcolm Toon]] presented to a Russian delegation ''K-129''{{'}}s [[ship's bell]].{{rp|262}} According to ''Red Star Rogue'', this bell had been permanently attached to the middle of the [[conning tower]] of ''K-129'', thus indicating that in addition to the bow of the submarine, the critical and valuable midsection of the submarine was at least partially recovered by Project Azorian. Additionally, Ambassador Toon is quoted from the 6th Plenum of the [[U.S.–Russia Joint Commission on POW/MIAs]] {{rp|262}} as stating, "Our director of naval intelligence has concluded that no U.S. sub was within 300 nautical miles of your sub when it sank". ''Red Star Rogue'' places K-129 at 24deg north latitude by 163 west longitude, less than 350 miles from Honolulu. This site is consistent with the discovery of radioactive oil{{rp|216}} reported to the Hawaii Institute of Geophysical Research at the time. The premise of ''Red Star Rogue'' is that a fail-safe device designed to be activated in the event of an unauthorised fire command of its nuclear missiles caused 2 catastrophic explosions (monitored by U.S. technology at the time) resulting in sinking the submarine. The 11 extra crewmen have never been satisfactorily identified, and K-129's crew manifest was listed as missing by Russian authorities. An ID photograph of a sailor found in the wreck has never been identified.{{cite book|title=Red Star Rogue|last=Sewell|first=Kenneth|year=2005|publisher=Simon&Schuster|pages= |isbn=0-7432-6112-7}} ''Red Star Rogue'' claims the changing relations with China and Russia in the early 1970s, forged by Nixon and Kissinger, were enabled by the K-129 incident. Craven suggests that Project Azorian's real goal was not the nuclear weapons or the coding systems at all; rather, the project sought to determine exactly what ''K-129'' was doing at '''40N/180W''' "where she did not belong". Such information could be (and supposedly was) utilized within [[Henry Kissinger]]'s foreign policy of "[[Deterrence Through Uncertainty]]", in order to "raise an unanswerable question in [[Leonid Brezhnev]]'s mind about his command and control of his armed forces".{{rp|221}} ===Mutual agreement: some connection between ''K-129'' and the loss of USS ''Scorpion''=== Retired United States Navy Captain [[Peter Huchthausen]], former naval attaché in Moscow, had a brief conversation in 1987 with Soviet admirals concerning ''K-129''. Huchthausen states that Admiral Peter Navojtsev told him, "Captain, you are very young and inexperienced, but you will learn that there were some matters that both nations have agreed to not discuss, and one of these is the reasons we lost K-129." In 1995, when Huchthausen began work on a book about the Soviet underwater fleet, he interviewed Admiral Victor Dygalo, who stated that the true history of ''K-129'' has not been revealed because of the informal agreement between the two countries' senior naval commands. The purpose of that secrecy, he alleged, is to stop any further research into the losses of USS ''Scorpion'' and ''K-129''. Huchthausen states that Dygalo told him to "overlook this matter, and hope that the time will come when the truth will be told to the families of the victims." ==Gates' visit to Moscow== In October 1992, [[Robert Gates]], as the [[Director of Central Intelligence]], visited Moscow to meet with President [[Boris Yeltsin]] of Russia. He said: {{quote|As a gesture of intent, a symbol of a new era, I carried with me the [[List of USSR navy flags|Soviet naval flag]] that had shrouded the coffins of the half dozen Soviet sailors whose remains the [[Glomar Explorer]] had recovered when it raised part of a Soviet ballistic missile submarine from deep in the Pacific Ocean in the mid-1970s, I also was taking to Yeltsin a videotape of their burial at sea, complete with prayers for the dead and the [[Soviet national anthem]] – a dignified and respectful service even at the height of the Cold War. {{cite book |title=From the Shadows |last=Gates |first=Robert |year=1996 |publisher=Touchstone |pages=553–54 |isbn=0-684-81081-6 }}}} Gates's decision to bring the videotape of the funeral held for the men on the Golf was ultimately motivated by the fact that the United States wanted to inspire Russia to offer up information on [[Vietnam War POW/MIA issue|missing American servicemen in Vietnam]]. Before that, "We had never confirmed anything to the Russians except in various vague senses," he said in an interview. {{quote|Shortly after [[Fall of the USSR|the USSR collapsed]], the [[George H.W. Bush|Bush]] administration had told the Russians through an intermediary that we couldn't tell them any more about what had happened on Golf/''Glomar''. But then when we started asking the Russians about what had happened to U.S. pilots shot down over Vietnam, and if any U.S. POWs had been transferred to Russia and held there, they came back and said, "What about our guys in the submarine?" At the time, the administration told the Russians only that there were no survivors and that there were only scattered remains.}} A subsequent FOIA search to find if any POWs were released as a result of this visit produced only negative results. {{cite book |last=Sontag |first=Sherry |year=1998 |title=Blind Man's Bluff: The Untold Story of American Submarine Espionage |publisher=Harper |isbn=0-06-103004-X |page=486 }} According to Peter Huchthausen: {{quote |American officers have refuted the Russian charge made early on that American nuclear attack submarine U.S.S. ''Swordfish'' was the U.S. submarine involved – a charge based solely on the latter's reported arrival in the Ship Repair Facility, Yokosuka, Japan, on 17 March 1968, with a badly damaged sail. Retired U.S. Navy Admiral [[William D. Smith]] informed Dygalo by letter following a 31 August 1994, meeting of a Joint U.S./Russia Commission examining questions of Cold War and previous war missing, that the allegation of Swordfish's involvement was not correct and that ''Swordfish'' was nowhere near the Golf on 8 March 1968. The joint commission, headed by General Volkogonov and Ambassador Toon, informed the Russians that no U.S. submarines on 8 March 1968, had been within {{convert|300|nmi|km|-1}} of the site where the K-129 was found. {{cite book |title=K19, The Widowmaker |last=Huchthausen |first=Peter |year=2002 |publisher=[[National Geographic Society]] |isbn=0-7922-6472-X |page=177 }}}} ==See also== * ''[[Phantom (2013 film)|Phantom]]'' (2013 movie), loosely based on ''K-129''. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book |last=Craven |first=John |authorlink=John Piña Craven |title=The Silent War: The Cold War Battle Beneath the Sea |year=2001 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=0-684-87213-7 |chapter=The Hunt for Red September: A Tale of Two Submarines |pages=198–222 }} * {{cite book |last=Sontag |first=Sherry | title=Blind Man's Bluff: The Untold Story of American Submarine Espionage. |year=1998 |publisher=Harper |location=New York | isbn=0-06-103004-X}} * {{cite book |last=Sewell |first=Kenneth | title=Red Star Rogue: The untold story of a Soviet submarine's nuclear strike attempt on the U.S. |year=2005 |publisher=Simon & '''Stephanie Arnold''' (born July 7, 1971) is an American producer and author.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nyemmys.org/nominations/44th%20Annual%20New%20York%20Emmy%20Awards.pdf|title=Emmy Awards|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sdjewishworld.com/2014/05/12/mother-survived-death-says-trust-premonitions/|title=Mother who survived death says trust your premonitions|last=McCafferty|first=Janice|date=|website=San Diego Jewish World|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> In 2013, she was clinically dead for 37 seconds after suffering an [[amniotic fluid embolism]] (AFE) immediately after giving birth to her second child.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.afesupport.org/stephanie-arnold-director/|title=Stephanie Arnold, Director|last=|first=|date=|work=Amniotic Fluid Embolism Foundation|access-date=2018-03-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> On September 15, 2015 Arnold published a book, ''37 Seconds,'' about the event and her life afterwards.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/921440522|title=37 seconds : dying revealed heaven's help--a mother's journey|last=Stephanie.|first=Arnold,|isbn=9780062402332|edition= First |location=San Francisco|oclc=921440522}}</ref> The book has since been translated into several languages. Her cousin, Sari Padorr also collaborated on her book.
== Personal life == In May 2013, Stephanie Arnold suffered a rare and often fatal, a condition called. an amniotic fluid embolism after giving birth to her second child and she died on the operating table.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://afesupport.org/stephanie-arnold-director/|title=AFE Foundation website|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Arnold later covered this, along with the events before and after her clinical death in her 2015 book.<ref name=":4" />
Arnold is married to PhD economist (University of Chicago) Jonathan Arnold, with whom she has three children.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://chicagoecon.com|title=Chicago Econ|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Career == After graduation, Arnold worked for Higher Authority Productions in Miami, producing Jewish educational documentaries.<ref name=":0" /> She then formed her own production company called Fisch Food Productions, Inc., where she held many roles including an executive producer for 14 years. Along with Fisch Food, she co-founded Busby, an invitation-only social network, where entertainment and media professional showcase, connect, and flourish. Throughout her career Stephanie produced television programs and music videos with the likes of Sarah Jessica Parker & Chris Noth (New York Magazine Award Show), Marc Anthony (Puerto Rican Day Parade) and Julio Iglesias (Baila Morena). In 1995, Arnold was nominated for a [[Lo Nuestro Awards|Premio Lo Nuestro]] for her direction in [[Olga Tañón|Olga Tañón’s]] ''[[Tu Amor o Tu Desprecio|Tu Amor]]'' video.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nyemmys.org/nominations/44th%20Annual%20New%20York%20Emmy%20Awards.pdf|title=Emmy Award Nominations|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Because of her work with music, she also served as a board member on the Florida chapter of the Grammys.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.grammy.com/pdfs/musicares/mc_csr_donor_pages.pdf|title=Grammy Musicares|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
Arnold produced other reality television programs including ''Elite Model’s Look of the Year''. She co-created and executive produced a show called ''Latin Access''''',''' the first nationally syndicated entertainment magazine television program focusing on Hispanic content in English.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://variety.com/2001/tv/news/nbc-to-bow-latin-access-1117799474/|title=Variety|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The show aired on the NBC owned and operated stations, along with many affiliates throughout the country.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/news-articles/latin-spin-access/97003|title=Latin spin for Access|last=|first=|date=|website=Broadcasting & Cable|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref> Throughout her career, she also served as Vice President of Development for the Production Company responsible for Surreal Life, Mindless Entertainment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.51minds.com/|title=51 Minds|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In addition to Mindless, she was Senior Vice President of Development for Galan Entertainment, a Latin media company.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://galanent.com|title=Galan|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Later, in the fall of 2003 Arnold was hired by the production company [[Endemol]] to launch their US Hispanic division.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5" /> During her time there, she ran the show and executive produced ''[[Vas o No Vas (U.S. game show)|Vas or No Vas]]'' for Telemundo.<ref name=":2" />
Today, Stephanie Arnold currently serves on the board of directors for the AFE Foundation, and was named one of Today’s Chicago Woman’s 100 Women of Inspiration,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.paramounteventschicago.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/TCWJuly14_100WOMEN.pdf|title=100 Women of Inspiration|last=|first=|date=|website=Today's Chicago Women|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and speaks on patient advocacy to organizations like The American Society of Anesthesiologist and featured in their campaign "When Seconds Count". She talks to clinicians and students at the Association of Women's Health Obstetrics and Neonatal Nurses (AWHONN). She has worked with University of Chicago (Divinity and Medical School), groups at the Department of Defense, Chicago Ideas Week, and has raised money for Northwestern Memorial Hospital's Prentice Women's Hospital. She was also the focus of the Mothers of May campaign for LifeSource Blood Donation Services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lifesource.org/37seconds/|title=37 seconds|last=|first=|date=|website=LifeSource|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
37 Seconds is Stephanie Arnold's first book. It is a book about survival, premonitions, intuition, the past, the present, and the future. A true-life story of survival and how dying revealed Heaven's help. The book has won several awards including The Reader's Favorite Gold Medal and became a National Bestseller.
== Bibliography == * ''37 Seconds'' (2015)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://reviews.libraryjournal.com/2016/04/best-sellers/spiritual-living-best-sellers-april-2016/|title=Spiritual Living: Best Sellers, April 2016|last=|first=|date=|work=Library Journal Reviews|access-date=2018-03-19|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>

{{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = The Peaceful Pill Handbook | image = The Peaceful Pill Handbook cover.jpg | image_size = | alt = Cover of The Peaceful Pill Handbook | caption = Australian cover | author = [[Philip Nitschke]] and Fiona Stewart | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = Euthanasia | genre = | set_in = | published = | publisher = [[Exit International]] US | publisher2 = | pub_date = July 1, 2006 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print and Digital | pages = 214 | awards = | isbn = 0-9788788-2-5 | isbn_note = | oclc = 245542475 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = http://www.peacefulpillhandbook.com }}
'''''The Peaceful Pill Handbook''''' is a book setting out information on [[assisted suicide]] and [[voluntary euthanasia]]. It was originally published in the U.S. in 2006 and was written by the Australian doctors [[Philip Nitschke]] and [[Fiona Stewart (author)|Fiona Stewart]]. In 2008 the on-line handbook was launched. Called ''The Peaceful Pill eHandbook'', it contains video clips on assisted suicide and voluntary euthanasia methods and related issues, but does not provide "how-to" instructions. The eHandbook is updated six times a year. A [[German language|German]] edition of the print book — ''Die Friedliche Pille'' — was published in 2011. A [[French language|French]] edition — ''La Pilule Paisible'' — was published in June 2015.
==Content== The book is primarily intended for [[old age#senior citizen|senior]]s, people who are seriously ill and their families and friends. It is also a resource guide for those working in public health and aged care. The book rates over 15 approaches to euthanasia according to reliability and peacefulness scales.
Strategies covered by the books include: the use of gases (such as [[nitrogen]]), [[poison]]s such as [[carbon monoxide]], non-prescription drugs such as [[chloroquine]], prescription drugs such as [[insulin]] and the [[opiate]]s and former [[prescription drug]]s such as the [[barbiturate]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lacey|first=Marc|title=In Tijuana, a Market for Death in a Bottle|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/21/world/americas/21tijuana.html?fta=y&pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=January 14, 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 21, 2008}}</ref> The book details lawful means of obtaining and administering the drugs and other peripheral issues such as drug storage, [[shelf life]] and disposal. The [[Switzerland|Swiss]] assisted suicide services are also covered in detail, as are issues such as the writing of [[will and testament|will]]s, [[advance health care directive|advance directives]] and issues of determining testamentary and decision making capacity.
One of the more controversial aspects of the book is its coverage of the Internet as a source of drugs. To this end, the authors publish a regular [[neighborhood watch|neighbourhood watch]] that warns about internet [[confidence trick|scammers]] and fake and fraudulent [[website]]s.
==Reception== Although restricted in New Zealand and Australia, the book is available without restriction on [[Amazon.com]], Amazon.co.uk and from the Peacefulpillstore.com website.
===Australia=== While the book was initially granted an 18+ rating in [[Australia]], this was overturned on appeal from the [[Attorney-General for Australia|Australian Attorney-General]]. In early 2007 the publication was refused classification (RC) by the [[Australian Classification Board|Classification Board]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200702/s1856344.htm |title=Classification board defends euthanasia book ban. 25 February 2007. ABC News Online |publisher=www.abc.net.au |accessdate=2010-06-14 }}</ref> In 2009, the Australian government included the handbook website in its [[Internet censorship in Australia|internet filtering plan]] known as the Clean Feed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/conroy-urged-to-end-net-censorship-farce-20090902-f7n3.html |title=Conroy urged to 'end net censorship farce' |publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |accessdate=2009-09-03 | first=Asher | last=Moses | date=2009-09-02}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== In 2008, the [[Society for Promotion of Community Standards]] objected to the book’s publication. This led to its temporary banning in New Zealand on the grounds that it was an objectionable publication.<ref>[http://www.censorship.govt.nz/news-archive-current-peacefulpill.html Office of Film & Literature Classification] – "The Peaceful Pill Handbook banned"</ref> A short time later the book was republished in redacted form and is available if sealed and an indication of the censorship classification is displayed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.smh.com.au/world/ban-on-euthanasia-book-lifted-in-nz-20080511-2cxv.html |title=Ban on euthanasia book lifted in NZ |publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |accessdate=2010-06-14 |date=2008-05-11}}</ref><ref>[http://www.censorship.govt.nz/pdfword/peaceful%20pill%20s38.pdf Office of Film & Literature Classification]</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Final Exit]]'' by [[Derek Humphry]] * ''[[The Complete Manual of Suicide]]'' by Wataru Tsurumi * [[Suicide]] * [[Suicide methods]] * [[Euthanasia device]] * [[Jack Kevorkian]]

{{good article}} [[File:Alanna Spence - queen bee (by).jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Worker policing is found in [[honey bee]]s and other [[hymenoptera]]ns including some species of [[bumblebee]]s, [[ants]] and [[wasps]].]]
'''Worker policing''' is a behavior seen in colonies of social [[hymenoptera]]ns ([[ants]], [[bees]], and [[wasps]]) whereby [[worker (bee)|worker females]] eat or remove eggs that have been laid by other workers rather than those laid by a queen. Worker policing ensures that the offspring of the queen will predominate in the group. In certain species of bees, ants and wasps, workers or the queen may also act aggressively towards fertile workers. Worker policing has been suggested as a form of [[coercion]] to promote the evolution of [[altruism in animals|altruistic]] behavior in [[Eusociality|eusocial]] insect societies.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ratnieks |first=Francis L. W. |author2=Heikki Helanterä |title=The evolution of extreme altruism and inequality in insect societies |journal=Phil. Trans. R. Soc. B|date=October 2009 |volume=364 |issue=1553 |pages=3169–3179 |doi=10.1098/rstb.2009.0129 |url=http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/364/1533/3169.full |pmid=19805425 |pmc=2781879}}</ref>
Proposed mechanisms for the recognition of worker-laid eggs or active reproductive workers include marker hydrocarbons on the surface of queen-laid eggs, cuticle hydrocarbons on reproductive workers, and recognition of nest-mates.<ref name=Queen.Hydrocarbon>{{cite journal| last=Endler| first=Annett|author2=Jürgen Liebig |author3=Bert Hölldobler | title=Queen fertility, egg marking and colony size in the ant ''Camponotus floridanus''| journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|date=February 2006| volume=59|issue=4| pages=490–499| doi=10.1007/s00265-005-0073-0| url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs00265-005-0073-0?LI=true#page-1}}</ref><ref name=Worker.Hydrocarbon>{{cite journal| last=Hartmann| first=Anne|author2=Patrizia D'Ettorre |author3=Graeme R. Jones |author4=Jürgen Heinze | title=Fertility signaling—the proximate mechanism of worker policing in a clonal ant| journal=Naturwissenschaften|date=June 2005| volume=92| issue=6| pages=282–286| doi=10.1007/s00114-005-0625-1| url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs00114-005-0625-1 | pmid=15770464}}</ref><ref name=Nestmate.Recognition>{{cite journal| last=Helanterä| first=Heikki|author2=Liselotte Sundström |title=Worker policing and nest mate recognition in the ant ''Formica fusca''| journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|date=June 2007| volume=61| issue=8| pages=1143–1149| doi=10.1007/s00265-006-0327-5| url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs00265-006-0327-5?LI=true}}</ref> In rare cases, worker-laid eggs carry mimicked queen hydrocarbons and escape policing, a condition known as the anarchic syndrome.<ref name=Anarchic.Syndrome>{{cite journal| last=Oldroyd| first=Benjamin P.|author2=Katherine E Osborne | title=The evolution of worker sterility in honeybees: the genetic basis of failure of worker policing| journal=Proc. R. Soc. Lond. B|date=July 1999| volume=266| issue=1426| pages=1335–1339| doi=10.1098/rspb.1999.0784| url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/266/1426/1335.abstract| pmc=1690071}}</ref>
Not all forms of policing require the presence of a queen; it also occurs in a few species of ants which establish a [[dominance hierarchy]] of reproductive female workers, where top-ranking individuals reproduce.<ref name=Selfishpolicing >{{cite journal|last=Stroeymeyt|first=Nathalie |author2=Elisabeth Brunner |author3=Jürgen Heinze|title="Selfish worker policing" controls reproduction in a ''Temnothorax'' ant|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|date=July 2007|volume=61|issue=9|pages=1449–1457|doi=10.1007/s00265-007-0377-3|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs00265-007-0377-3?LI=true}}</ref>
==Evolutionary basis== {{See also|Haplodiploidy}}
[[File:Haplodiploid-sex-determination-system3.png|thumb|upright|The [[Haplodiploidy|haplodiploid]] sex determination system has consequences for worker policing behavior]] In many [[Eusociality|social insect]] communities, sex is determined through [[haplodiploidy]]. [[Haploid]] male [[Drone (bee)|drone]]s develop from unfertilized eggs while [[diploid]] females develop from fertilized eggs. Queens of a colony may mate with one or several drones. On average, a queen shares half of her genes with her sons, but only shares a quarter of her genes with the sons of fertile female workers. Therefore, it is in the queen's best interests to have her own sons raised, and not the sons of workers. Workers can reproduce in many ants, bees, and wasps because male offspring come from unfertilized eggs.<ref name=Policing.Bee/>
By contrast, the worker shares half of her genes with her sons and only a quarter with her brothers. Furthermore, the workers in colonies with a single once-mated queen are related to their nephews by three eighths, higher than they are related to brothers. This results in a conflict where the queen and worker females are at odds over the proportion of male offspring they contribute, since each side tries to maximize its [[reproductive fitness]].<ref name=Policing.Bee>{{cite journal|last=Ratnieks|first=Francis L.W.|author2=P. Kirk Visscher |title=Worker policing in the honeybee|journal=Nature|date=December 1989|volume=342|issue=6251|pages=796–797|doi=10.1038/342796a0|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v342/n6251/abs/342796a0.html|bibcode=1989Natur.342..796R}}</ref> Queens favor production of their own sons while workers favor production of their own sons, and do not stop their sisters from laying because of the favorable relatedness to nephews.
Worker policing occurs when worker bees in the colony are genetically more [[Coefficient of relationship|closely related]] to the queen than the reproductive female. In many instances, the eggs of the female worker are eaten, or she is repeatedly attacked by other workers. This mechanism of egg removal ensures that the queen's sons predominate.<ref name=Resistance>{{cite journal|last=Wenseleers|first=Tom|author2=Adam G. Hart |author3=Francis L. W. Ratnieks |title=When Resistance Is Useless: Policing and the Evolution of Reproductive Acquiescence in Insect Societies|journal=The American Naturalist|date=December 2004|volume=164|issue=6|pages=E154-E167|doi=10.1086/425223|jstor=10.1086/425223|publisher=The University of Chicago Press for The American Society of Naturalists}}</ref>
Experiments confirming the role of [[kin selection]] in worker policing demonstrate the effects of multiple matings, which can lead to lower average relatedness between workers. Queens of the social wasp ''[[Dolichovespula saxonica]]'' mate singly or multiply. Researchers who study these wasps have observed a strong positive correlation between worker relatedness and male production. After controlling for the absolute number of eggs laid, these scientists conclude that the queen's multiple matings favor mutual worker policing.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Foster|first=Kevin R.|author2=Francis L.W. Ratnieks |title=Social insects: Facultative worker policing in a wasp|journal=Nature|date=October 2000|volume=407|issue=6805|pages=692–693|doi=10.1038/35037665|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v407/n6805/full/407692a0.html}}</ref>
Although early theories of worker policing focused on the kin selection component, evidence from [[Apis mellifera|honey bees]] suggests that [[altruism]] is sometimes enforced. Fewer workers reproduce as policing effectiveness rises, and policing effectiveness decreases with increasing relatedness except in colonies with no queen. This suggests that worker policing is a social sanction imposed on [[Gene-centered view of evolution#Selfish-gene theory|selfish individuals]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wenseleers|first=Tom|author2=Francis L. W. Ratnieks |title=Enforced altruism in insect societies|journal=Nature|date=November 2006|volume=444|issue=7115|pages=50|doi=10.1038/444050a|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v444/n7115/full/444050a.html}}</ref>
==Proposed mechanisms for kin recognition==
[[File:Fusca feeding.jpg|thumb|''[[Formica fusca]]'' ants can recognize nest-mates]]
Mechanisms suggested for egg discrimination in worker policing include queen hydrocarbons, fertile worker hydrocarbons, and nestmate recognition.
===Queen hydrocarbons===
A study on the [[carpenter ant]] ''Camponotus floridanus'' found a special surface [[hydrocarbon]] on queen-laid eggs. Workers in the colony with the queen's eggs refrained from egg-laying, whereas other groups that did not have queen-laid eggs showed worker reproduction. Thus, the hydrocarbon could act as a signal to alert workers to halt reproduction. More generally, however, the authors concluded that the hydrocarbons were a fertility signal. It is still unknown as to how the decision to restrain reproduction occurs or what minimum threshold of fertility in the queen is needed to reduce worker reproduction.<ref name=Queen.Hydrocarbon/>
===Fertile worker hydrocarbons===
The study of cuticle hydrocarbons has also been applied to the reproductive workers. In some colonies of the ponerine ant ''[[Platythyrea punctata]]'', the presence of CHCs in new reproductive workers triggered aggressive behavior from the rest of the colony, often between new and old reproductive workers. Specifically, the old reproductive workers rubbed a marker hydrocarbon on the [[Antenna (biology)|antennae]] of the new females, identifying them as rivals and targets for aggression.<ref name=Worker.Hydrocarbon/>
===Nestmate recognition===
In contrast to the other ant species, worker policing in the ant ''[[Formica fusca]]'' appears to incorporate nestmate recognition in addition to the queen hydrocarbons. Workers displayed higher levels of aggression toward non-nest mates and also removed some queen-laid eggs. Thus, queen hydrocarbons were not the only contributor to discrimination of the eggs.<ref name=Nestmate.Recognition/>
==Examples from social Hymenoptera== Worker policing has [[Convergent evolution|evolved convergently]] in several social insect species. The following cases are examples:
=== Bees === [[File:Apis mellifera carnica worker honeycomb 3.jpg|thumb|upright|''[[Apis mellifera]]'' workers remove worker-laid eggs by eating them (oophagy)]]
One of the first examples of worker policing to be discovered was in the honey bee, ''[[Apis mellifera]]''. Worker policing is prevalent in most honey bee colonies, and worker reproduction is minimal (0.12%) in this species.<ref name=Quant.Study.Bee>{{cite journal|last=Visscher|first=P. Kirk|title=A quantitative study of worker reproduction in honey bee colonies|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|year=1989|volume=25|issue=4|pages=247–254|jstor=4600337|doi=10.1007/bf00300050}}</ref> Worker policing occurs via egg-eating ([[oophagy]]) in ''Apis mellifera'' colonies.<ref name=Resistance/> In many of these hives, the activation of ovaries in fertile females is diminished, suggesting that there are disincentives to laying eggs.<ref name=Resistance/>
Workers in colonies of the Asian honey bee, ''[[Apis florea]]'', are also reported to engage in oophagy. Using [[microsatellite]] analysis, researchers concluded that no mature drones had non-queen alleles in the colonies they investigated. Thus, even though workers had activated ovaries and were capable of laying eggs, worker policing ensured the functional sterility of otherwise fertile workers.<ref name=wp_a.florea>{{cite journal| last=Halling| first=Luke A|author2=Benjamin P. Oldroyd |author3=Wandee Wattanachaiyingcharoen |author4=Andrew B. Barron |author5=Piyamas Nanork |author6=Siriwat Wongsiri |title=Worker policing in the bee ''Apis florea''| journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology| year=2001| volume=49| issue=6| pages=509–513| url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs002650100325| doi=10.1007/s002650100325|publisher=Springer-Verlag}}</ref>
A higher percentage of female workers of the bee species ''[[Apis cerana]]'' are reported to activate their ovaries than those of ''Apis mellifera'' or ''Apis florea''. When queens were removed, up to 40% of the workers activated their ovaries in subsequent days. However, policing workers continued to eat the worker-laid eggs, suggesting that the mechanism of policing in this species does not involve direct intervention from the queen.<ref name=wp_a.cerana>{{cite journal| last=Oldroyd| first=Benjamin P.|author2=Luke A. Halling |author3=Gregory Good |author4=Wandee Wattanachaiyingcharoen |author5=Andrew B. Barron |author6=Piyamas Nanork |author7=Siriwat Wongsiri |author8=Francis L. Ratnieks | title=Worker policing and worker reproduction in ''Apis cerana''| journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology| year=2001| volume=50| issue=4| pages=371–377| url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs002650100376|doi=10.1007/s002650100376| publisher=Springer-Verlag}}</ref>
The observation that all these [[Apis (genus)|Apis]] species engage in [[polyandry]] has led researchers to conclude that worker policing is [[plesiomorphic]] for the Apis genus.<ref name=wp_a.cerana/>
Worker policing also occurs in the primitively eusocial [[bumblebee]]s such as ''[[Bombus terrestris]]''.<ref name=Zanette>{{cite journal |last1=Zanette |first1=L. R. |last2=Miller |first2=S. D. |last3=Faria |first3=C. M.|last4=Almond |first4=E. J. |last5=Huggins |first5=T. J.|last6=Jordan |first6=W. C. |last7=Bourke |first7=A. F. |title=Reproductive conflict in bumblebees and the evolution of worker policing |journal=Evolution |date=December 2012 |volume=66 |issue=12 |pages=3765–3777 |doi=10.1111/j.1558-5646.2012.01709.x |pmid=23206135}}</ref>
=== Ants === [[File:Harpegnathos saltator fight.jpg|thumb|Worker of ''[[Harpegnathos saltator]]'' killing a queen]]
{{further information|Gamergate}}
In colonies of the ponerine ant, ''Pachycondyla inversa,'' workers eat the eggs of fertile female workers, known as [[gamergate]]s, and display aggressive behavior towards egg-laying females.<ref>{{cite journal| last=D'Ettorre| first=Patrizia|author2=Jürgen Heinze |author3=Francis L W Ratnieks | title=Worker policing by egg eating in the ponerine ant ''Pachycondyla inversa''| journal=Proc Biol Sci|date=July 2004| volume=271| issue=1546| pages=1427–1434| doi=10.1098/rspb.2004.2742| pmc=1691738| pmid=15306343}}</ref>
In colonies of the ant ''Gnamptogenys menadensis'', workers will sometimes mate and lay eggs while others remain as virgins to lay [[trophic egg]]s to be used as food. In a display of policing, workers can immobilize female reproductive workers by biting their limbs; it is reported that 50% of the victims die from this treatment. The attacking workers may also drag offending workers outside the colony. Since workers can lay both male and female eggs, worker policing could be favored as the cost to the community is large.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gobin| first=Bruno |author2=J. Billen |author3=C. Peeters| title=Policing behaviour towards virgin egg layers in a polygynous ponerine ant |journal=Anim. Behav. |date=November 1999| volume=58| issue=5| pages=1117–1122 |pmid=10564615| doi=10.1006/anbe.1999.1245}}</ref>
The ant species ''Aphaenogaster smythiesi japonica'' also display evidence of policing. When researchers separated and then reunited workers from colonies that did or did not have queens, workers from the queen-containing colonies attacked the workers with activated ovaries from the queenless colonies.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Iwanishi |first=Satoru |author2=Eisuke Hasegawab |author3=Kyohsuke Ohkawaraa| title=Worker oviposition and policing behaviour in the myrmicine ant ''Aphaenogaster smythiesi japonica'' Forel| journal=Animal Behaviour |date=September 2003| volume=66| issue=3| pages=513–519| doi=10.1006/anbe.2003.2222 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347203922226}}</ref>
In the queenless ant ''Streblognathus peetersi'', policing helps to select gamergates. The workers immobilize gamergates with lowered fertility, enabling high-ranking workers to take over as new gamergates.<ref name="GadauFewell2009">{{cite book |last1=Gadau |first1=Jürgen |last2=Fewell |first2=Jennifer |last3=Wilson |first3=Edward O. |authorlink3=Edward O. Wilson|title=Organization of Insect Societies: From Genome to Sociocomplexity |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_79XeC-xvCcC&pg=PA227 |year=2009 |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=978-0-674-03125-8 |pages=227–228}}</ref>
In the ponerine ant ''[[Harpegnathos saltator]]'', worker policing prevents the number of reproductive workers from becoming excessive. The species has gamergates, which lay eggs but rarely carry out any other tasks, so having too many of them would reduce the colony's efficiency. Gamergate numbers are rather stable, as infertile workers target newly ovipositing workers by jumping on and holding them: this efficiently inhibits them from laying eggs, and within a few weeks they revert to being subordinate and infertile workers. However, once new ovipositing workers attain a gamergate's level of ovarian activity, the infertile (policing) workers ignore them. The signal used by the policing workers consists of cuticle hydrocarbons transmitted only by direct contact, rather than being a [[pheromone]] detected by [[olfaction]]. Similarly, the inhibition of ovipositing workers is achieved by direct physical aggression by policing workers, not by any pheromone produced by queens or gamergates.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Liebig |first1=Jürgen |last2=Peeters |first2=Christian |last3=Höllldobler |first3=Bert |title=Worker policing limits the number of reproductives in a ponerine ant |journal=Proc. R. Soc. Lond. B|date=1999 |volume=266 |pages=1865–1870 |doi=10.1098/rspb.1999.0858|pmc=1690207 }}</ref>
=== Wasps === [[File:GemeineWespe2.jpg|thumb|''[[Dolichovespula sylvestris]]'' workers can display aggression towards other fertile workers]] The tree wasp ''[[Dolichovespula sylvestris]]'' also displays worker policing. Both egg-eating and aggression are reported in these wasp communities, and the queen also engages in the policing process.<ref>{{cite journal| last=Wenseleers| first=Tom |author2=A. Tofilski |author3=F. L. W. Ratnieks|title=Queen and worker policing in the tree wasp ''Dolichovespula sylvestris''|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology| year=2005| volume=58| pages=80–86| doi=10.1007/s00265-004-0892-4}}</ref> Similar behavior has been observed in the closely related species ''[[Dolichovespula media]]''.<ref name="Foster">{{cite journal|last1=Foster|first1=Kevin R.|title=Colony kin structure and male production in ''Dolichovespula'' wasps|journal=Molecular Ecology|date=2001|volume=10|pages=1003–1010| accessdate=10 October 2014|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1365-294X.2001.01228.x/pdf|doi=10.1046/j.1365-294X.2001.01228.x}}</ref>
In colonies of the paper wasp, ''[[Polistes chinensis|Polistes chinensis antennalis]]'', workers can lay up to a quarter of the male eggs in the colony. The number of eggs that survived to hatching, however, was minimal compared to the number produced by the queen. Analysis of the microsatellite markers showed that both queens and workers contributed to policing of worker and queen-laid eggs even in [[Monogyny|monogynous]] and monandrous colonies.<ref>{{cite journal| last=Saigo| first=T.|author2=K. Tsuchida | title=Queen and worker policing in monogynous and monandrous colonies of a primitively eusocial wasp|date=December 2004| volume=271| pages=S509–S512| pmc=1810092| pmid=15801618| doi=10.1098/rsbl.2004.0238| journal=Proc Biol Sci}}</ref>
The common wasp, ''[[Vespula vulgaris]]'', engages in worker policing, and it is known that a significant number of workers have active ovaries. However, studies by researchers have suggested that relatedness may not be the key factor in the development of worker policing. Rather, it is hypothesized that worker policing has been selected due to conflict suppression in the colony.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Foster|first=Kevin R.|author2=Francis L. W. Ratnieks |title=Convergent evolution of worker policing by egg eating in the honeybee and common wasp|journal=Proc Biol Sci|date=January 2001|volume=268|issue=1463|pages=169–74|doi=10.1098/rspb.2000.1346|url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/268/1463/169.long}}</ref>
In a test of worker policing, researchers examined the removal of worker-laid eggs in ''[[Vespula rufa]]'', a wasp that has low paternity. Under the testing conditions, worker policing was not as efficient, and some of the drones appeared to be from worker-laid eggs.<ref>{{cite journal| last=Wenseleers| first=Tom|author2=N. S. Badcock |author3=K. Erven |author4=A. Tofilski |author5=F. S. Nascimento |author6=A. G. Hart |author7=T. A. Burke |author8=M. E. Archer |author9=F. L W. Ratnieks | title=A test of worker policing theory in an advanced eusocial wasp, ''Vespula rufa''| journal=Evolution|date=June 2005| volume=59| issue=6| pages=1306–14| doi=10.1554/04-532| url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/abs/10.1554/04-532}}</ref>
The [[European Hornet]], ''Vespa crabro'', was previously thought to be under reproductive pheromone control by the queen, thus explaining why the other females didn't reproduce, even though they were capable of doing so. Experiments by Foster showed that the workers were instead regulating sterility in each other, thus instead exhibiting worker policing. While each worker is capable of reproducing, the colony as a whole is more efficient and organized if the workers allow only the queen to lay larvae.<ref name="police">{{cite journal | author=Foster, K.R., Gulliver, J., Ratnieks, F.L.W.| title=Worker policing in the European hornet Vespa crabro| journal=Insectes Sociaux| year=2002 | volume=49 | issue=1 | pages=41–44 | doi=10.1007/s00040-002-8277-z}}</ref>
''[[Synoeca cyanea]]'' also engage in worker policing during times when queen repopulation is not needed. They will prevent females from laying eggs through aggressive behavior and egg-eating.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Morphological and Physiological Caste Differences in Synoeca cyanea (Hymenoptero, Vespidae, Epiponini) According to the Ontogenetic Development of the Colonies|last = Noda|first = Silvia Cristina Mari|date = 2003|journal = Sociobiology|doi = |pmid = }}</ref>
== Exceptions ==
===Anarchic syndrome===
Very rarely, female worker bees lay eggs that escape worker policing, in a process known as the anarchic syndrome. Female reproductive workers in these colonies activate their ovaries even in the presence of a queen. The worker eggs are allowed as they [[mimicry|mimic]] queen hydrocarbons. Thus, female workers can maximize their reproductive fitness at the expense of the colony. Anarchic syndrome is an example of selection working in opposite directions at individual and group levels.<ref name=Anarchic.Syndrome />
===Selfish worker policing===
''[[Temnothorax unifasciatus]]'', a [[Myrmicinae|myrmicinid]] ant, has been shown not to have collective worker policing. However, when a queen is removed, a rank order for reproduction appears, where top ranking reproductives display aggression towards lower-order female workers. Thus, reductions in egg laying are created by [[Dominance hierarchy|dominance hierarchies]]. Individuals do not act in benefit of the colony, instead opting to increase their own fitness by laying their eggs and reducing the contributions of opponents.<ref name=Selfishpolicing />
This type of policy is common in [[Dolichovespula norwegica]] wasps where despite being more related to other workers’ sons, worker-laid eggs were consumed by other workers.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Co-occurrence of three types of egg policing in the Norwegian wasp Dolichovespsula wasp|last = Bonckaert|first = W.|date = 2001|journal = Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|doi = 10.1007/s00265-010-1064-3|pmid = |last2 = Tofilski|first2 = A.|last3 = Nascimento|first3 = F.S.|last4 = Billen|first4 = J.|last5 = Ratnieks|first5 = F.L.W.|last6 = Wenseleers|first6 = T. |volume=65 |pages=633–640}}</ref>
===Worker policing without genetic conflict===
In the [[Thelytoky|thelytokous]] ant ''Platythyrea punctata'', colonies are [[cloning|clonal]]; therefore, workers are all equally related genetically, and worker policing is not expected as there is no genetic conflict. However, one would expect severe effects on the condition of the colony if reproductive workers were left unchecked. For example, more time spent on individual reproduction would be predicted to detract from care of the queen's offspring. In studies of these ants, workers did actually display worker policing, as evidenced by increased aggression towards reproductive workers. Worker policing here is favored for group efficiency.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hartmann|first=Anne|author2=J. Wantia |author3=J. A. Torres |author4=J. Heinze | title=Worker policing without genetic conflicts in a clonal ant| journal=PNAS|date=October 2003| volume=100| issue=22| pages=12836–12840| doi=10.1073/pnas.2132993100| url=http://www.pnas.org/content/100/22/12836.abstract | pmid=14557542 | pmc=240705}}</ref>
